content.term: Stanford Type B Aortic Dissection Management
content.definition: Type B dissection (descending aorta only, not involving ascending) can be managed medically if uncomplicated. Complicated Type B (malperfusion, rupture, uncontrolled pain/hypertension, rapid expansion) requires urgent intervention, typically TEVAR. Medical therapy for uncomplicated Type B has lower early mortality than surgery.

stratification.complicated: Malperfusion, rupture, refractory pain/HTN, rapid expansion

management_uncomplicated: Serial imaging (CT at 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, then annually)
indications_for_intervention: Rapid aortic expansion (>1 cm/year or >5mm acute)
Aortic diameter >4 cm at initial presentation (ADSORB trial)
intervention_options: TEVAR: Entry tear coverage with stent graft (preferred)
Fenestration: Create communication between TL and FL
Open surgery: Reserved for TEVAR failure, connective tissue disease
TEVAR_technique: Landing zone proximal to left subclavian (may require revascularization)
Goal: expand true lumen, thrombose false lumen

clinical_pearls: Uncomplicated Type B = medical management (surgery has higher early mortality)
Complicated Type B = urgent intervention (usually TEVAR)
TEVAR has revolutionized complicated Type B outcomes
INSTEAD-XL, ADSORB trials show benefit of early TEVAR for selected patients
Long-term: 40% of medically-treated patients eventually need intervention

learning_objectives: Differentiate complicated vs uncomplicated Type B dissection
